TITLE:
   Chief Complaint:
   24 Hour Events:
   - attempted to wean sedation but patient became agitated and went back
   into AF [**Initials (NamePattern4) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern4) 1427**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] sedation was restarted
   - pushed IV metoprolol 2.5 x 2 with mild decrease in HR but no breaking
   of [**Name (NI) 1427**]
   - pt has converted back and forth
   - patient continued to spike fevers; per ID recs, switched from CTX -->
   CTZ + vanc + cipro for broader coverage of VAP (i.e. MRSA/Pseudomonas)
   - Cordis was pulled and BCx were sent from central line + culture tip
   of pulled Cordis
   - pt found to have asymmetric pupils on exam this AM, sent for CT
   head.  CT head showed hyperdense lesions worrisome for bleeding vs.
   metastasis in the cerebellum with no appreciable mass effect.  Mild SDH
   also noted.  NSGY was consulted; recommended MRI to better assess
   lesions.  Also advised repeat CT scan in a couple days to reassess
   bleeds; reconsider earlier scan if clinical scenario demands it.
   Heparin was discontinued.
   - nurse noted hard nonfixed subcutaneous mass on R arm (above elbow).
   Non-fluctuant, no transmitted pulses on exam; nurse is fairly certain
   this first appeared today.  No h/o sticks, IVs at that location.
   Continue to assess.
   - Patient remained persistently fluid positive despite lasix gtt @ 10
   cc/hr + IV boluses (first 80, followed by 100, followed by 100 +
   diuril).
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies

   This is a 65 year old male with a history of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and
   diabetes who presents with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough,
   increasing dyspnea and found to be in new-onset A.fib with [**Numeric Identifier 1427**] and
   markedly decreased EF with dilated LV, now s/p cardioversion x8, now
   with new [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma diagnosis.
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with [**Location (un) 1427**]: Believe this has been chronic, given
   dilated LV and decreased EF on echo; believed due to dilation from
   novel cardiomyopathy. He has not responded to multiple attempts at
   cardioversion.  HR first improved with digoxin, amiodarone and
   occasional use of esmolol gtt and pressors.  Refractory afib with
   difficult to control rates may be [**2-19**] pericardial irritation vs.
   inflammatory drive from malignancy; see below for onc management plan,
   also concern for metastatic cancer to myocardium.  Now back in atrial
   fibrillation despite previous sinus following cardioversion, AV node
   modification and pacer placement, and continuation of po Amiodarone.
   - continue Amiodarone gtt; discuss with EP how much is to be loaded
   before stopping
   - consider repeat cardioversion if patient is in atrial flutter
   - digoxin once weekly, 25% of original dose, per EP
   - heparin gtt stopped [**2-19**] CT head findings (CHADS score 2; hypertension
   and DM)
   - IV Metoprolol as needed to rate control in 120
   .
   # intracranial bleeds
 Patient was found to have asymmetric pupils on
   exam and received CT head c contrast [**11-12**].  This showed no lesion
   worrisome for mass effect, but two new lesions (R frontal, R
   cerebellar) were noted worrisome for metastasis vs. intraparenchymal
   hemorrhage in comparison to prior CT head one week ago.  NSGY was
   consulted and agreed with plan to d/c heparin gtt.
   -          heparin gtt d/ced
   -          MRI head w&w/o contrast to better assess etiology of lesions
   -          Consider repeat CT scan in several days to reassess
   bleeding, or earlier if clinical situation warrants.
   .
   # Cardiomyopathy: New-found EF of 20% with globally dilated RV.  Most
   likely tachycardia induced.  Was diuresed on Lasix drip initially, now
   monitoring central pressures with swan, currently volume overloaded but
   CVP WNL.  Appears to have significant diuretic resistance.
   - monitor I
s & O
s and cardiac index, titrate diuresis to CVP
   - ACE/BB once BP stabilizes and ARF improves
   - Lasix drip +/- bolus + metolazone for goal -1L today; will f/u I/O
   - continue statin
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock:  Likely [**2-19**] Afib with [**Month/Day (2) 1427**] and/or infection/sepsis,
   briefly on 2 pressors, currently only on norepinephrine.  Cardiac index
   WNL and improved with titration of pressors. SVR still low at 459.
   Worrisome for mixed cardiogenic / distributive shock picture.
   - Continue to monitor cardiac index serially
   - Goal negative 1.5L.

   - Appreciate ID recs; switched from CTX
 vanc + CTZ + ciprofloxacin

He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has been experiencing fevers, and his influenza screen was positive. Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. He presents with symptoms of malaise, dry cough, increasing dyspnea, and was found to be in new-onset atrial fibrillation with an ejection fraction of 20% and dilated left ventricle. He has undergone multiple cardioversions, but remains in atrial fibrillation. The patient has a diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma and is experiencing fevers, asymmetric pupils, asymmetric limb edema, confusion, and renal failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's persistent atrial fibrillation is refractory to cardioversion and amiodarone therapy. This may lead to complications such as stroke, heart failure, or thromboembolism.
2. Intracranial Bleeds: The patient's CT head shows new lesions worrisome for metastasis versus intraparenchymal hemorrhage. Further evaluation with an MRI is recommended to better assess the etiology of these lesions. If hemorrhagic, it could result in increased intracranial pressure and neurological deterioration.
3. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's significantly decreased ejection fraction and globally dilated right ventricle suggest tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. This condition can lead to heart failure and reduced cardiac output.
4. Hypotension/Shock: The patient's hypotension and low systemic vascular

   This is a 65 year old male with a history of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and
   diabetes who presents with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough,
   increasing dyspnea and found to be in new-onset A.fib with RVR and
   markedly decreased EF with dilated LV, now s/p cardioversion x8, now
   with new [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma diagnosis.
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: Believe this has been chronic, given
   dilated LV and decreased EF on echo; believed due to dilation from
   novel cardiomyopathy. He has not responded to multiple attempts at
   cardioversion.  HR first improved with digoxin, amiodarone and
   occasional use of esmolol gtt and pressors.  Refractory afib with
   difficult to control rates may be [**2-19**] pericardial irritation vs.
   inflammatory drive from malignancy; see below for onc management plan,
   also concern for metastatic cancer to myocardium.  Now back in atrial
   fibrillation despite previous sinus following cardioversion, AV node
   modification and pacer placement, and continuation of po Amiodarone.
   - continue Amiodarone gtt; as per EP
   - consider repeat cardioversion if patient is in atrial flutter
   - digoxin once weekly, 25% of original dose, per EP
   - heparin gtt stopped [**2-19**] CT head findings (CHADS score 2; hypertension
   and DM)
   - IV Metoprolol as needed to rate control in 120
   .
   # intracranial bleeds
 Patient was found to have asymmetric pupils on
   exam and received CT head c contrast [**11-12**].  This showed no lesion
   worrisome for mass effect, but two new lesions (R frontal, R
   cerebellar) were noted worrisome for metastasis vs. intraparenchymal
   hemorrhage in comparison to prior CT head one week ago.  NSGY was
   consulted and agreed with plan to d/c heparin gtt. (attending addendum
   to CT read) There is now a definite blood/fluid level, layering within
   a 14mm (AP) likely extra-axial collection, in the region of the right
   frontal operculum (2:18), suggesting evolving hemorrhage. Its relation
   to the more anteriorly-located well-defined hyperdense focus is
   unclear. The additional focus, along the right lateral aspect of the
   tentorium cerebelli, level of the ambient cistern, was not clearly
   present and also may represent evolving hemorrhage.
   -          heparin gtt d/ced
   -          MRI head w&w/o contrast to better assess etiology of lesions
   -          Consider repeat CT scan in several days to reassess
   bleeding, or earlier if clinical situation warrants.
   .
   # Cardiomyopathy: New-found EF of 20% with globally dilated RV.  Most
   likely tachycardia induced.  Was diuresed on Lasix drip initially, now
   monitoring central pressures with swan, currently volume overloaded but
   CVP WNL.  Appears to have significant diuretic resistance.
   - monitor I
s & O
s and cardiac index, titrate diuresis to CVP
   - ACE/BB once BP stabilizes and ARF improves
   - Lasix drip +/- bolus + metolazone for goal -1L today; will f/u I/O
   - continue statin
   - replace swan today
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock:  Likely [**2-19**] Afib with RVR and/or infection/sepsis,
   briefly on 2 pressors, currently only on norepinephrine.  Cardiac index
   WNL and improved with titration of pressors. SVR still low at 459.
   Worrisome for mixed cardiogenic / distributive shock picture.
   - Continue to monitor cardiac index serially once swan replaced
   - Goal negative (1-1.5L.)
   - Continue Amiodarone gtt
   - Norepinephrine
   - continue Vasopressin as needed
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated on [**11-4**]/9 for increased work of
   breathing. Required increase in ventilatory support o/n, but CXR this
   AM improved.
   - titrate vent settings to ABGs, wean to PSV as tolerated
   - Appreciate ID recs; switched from CTX
 vanc + CTZ + ciprofloxacin
   empirically for now.
   - await H1N1 results from government lab
   .
   # Fevers: (104.5 overnight) likely from positive influenza screen vs
   Merkell.  Switched famotidine to PPI out of concern for drug fever.
   -Continue Oseltamivir (d4-5), Ramantadine for influenza A
   - f/u blood and urine cultures as well as influenza H1N1 send out
   - repeat BCx, UCx, culture from line, consider broadening abx if
   continue to be febrile.
   - on CTZ, vanc, cipro per ID recs
   - CXR from [**2148-11-12**] showing worsened R lung infiltrates, improved L
   lung aeration
   .
   # [**Location (un) 10939**] Cell Carcinoma: Elevated LDH and finding of R axillary
   lymphadenopathy, CT torso showed c/w malignancy, biopsy consistent with
   Merckel Cell Carcinoma.  Poor prognosis at this time.
   - f/u Onc, expert recs
   - f/u Derm recs, as there is an attending familiar with [**Location (un) 10939**] Cell
   Carcinoma.
   - f/u MRI for results for ? brain mets
   - re-address code status
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: Crit stable, s/p transfusion.  Labs not
   concerning for DIC at this time.
   - Daily crit, transfuse for <25.
   - HIT antibodies negative
   - guaiac stools
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trending down from peak 2.8, 2.4 today up

   ?contribution of diuresis.  UOP adequate.  No indications for dialysis

   - Monitor [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes

   during this admission.   Sugars poorly controlled while in
patient,
   insulin drip intiated [**11-6**].
   - Continue Insulin drip

   # Neurologic changes:  Concern for metastasis of malignancy affecting
   CNS vs. thormboembolic event given a fib, particularly given recent
   L-sided extremity weakness and confusion.   CT head negative for acute
   event, but significant for mass suggestive of metastatic malignancy.

Summary:
Summary:
- 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes.
- Presenting with malaise, dry cough, increasing dyspnea, and found to be in new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
- Markedly decreased ejection fraction with dilated left ventricle.
- Cardioversion attempted multiple times, but not successful.
- New diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma.
- Multiple medical complications including intracranial bleeds, cardiomyopathy, hypotension/shock, respiratory failure, fevers, anemia/thrombocytopenia, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus type II, and neurologic changes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Intracranial bleeds: The presence of multiple enhancing lesions on MRI and hypodensity in the right cerebellar area suggests possible intracranial bleeding. Further evaluation is needed to determine the cause and severity of the bleed.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient has a significantly decreased ejection fraction (EF) of 20% with global dilation of the right ventricle. This may be due to tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy or metastatic cancer to the myocardium. Close monitoring and management are necessary.
3. Hypotension/Shock: The patient is currently on norepinephrine and has low systemic vascular resistance (SVR). This indicates potential hypotension or distributive shock. Care

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 74-year-old male with multiple medical conditions and complications. The patient's chief complaint and presenting symptoms are not clearly stated in the note. However, it appears that the patient is in the ICU for severe illness or injury.

The patient has a history of cancer (malignant neoplasm), anemia, respiratory failure, impaired skin integrity, fever, epistaxis, altered mental status, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus type II, and cardiomyopathy.

The note mentions several imaging findings, including multiple enhancing lesions on MRI and a new small hyperdense focus in the right frontal area, along with a hypodensity in the right cerebellar area, suggesting a possible subdural hemorrhage or new metastasis. There is also mention of opacification of mastoid air cells and right maxillary sinus without bony destruction, which may be related to intubation.

The patient's vital signs are unstable, with a maximum temperature of 104.5 degrees Celsius, blood pressure fluctuating between 125/57 mmHg and 149/65 mmHg, heart rate varying between 67-158 bpm, respiratory rate between 17-25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 97%. The patient's weight has decreased from 141 kg at admission to 139 kg currently.

The patient is receiving multiple medications, including antibiotics, vasopressin, and other ICU medications.

   Assessment and Plan
   Assessment and Plan
   This is a 65 year old male with a history of HTN, hyperlipidemia, and
   diabetes who presents with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough,
   increasing dyspnea and found to be in new-onset A.fib with RVR and
   markedly decreased EF with dilated LV, now s/p cardioversion x8, now
   with new [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma diagnosis.
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: Believe this has been chronic, given
   dilated LV and decreased EF on echo; believed due to dilation from
   novel cardiomyopathy. He has not responded to multiple attempts at
   cardioversion.  HR has improved with digoxin, amiodarone and occasional
   use of esmolol gtt and pressors.  Refractory afib with difficult to
   control rates may be [**2-19**] pericardial irritation vs. inflammatory drive
   from malignancy; see below for onc management plan, also concern for
   metastatic cancer to myocardium.  Now in and out of Afib, (currently
   sinus) despite previous sinus following cardioversion, AV node
   modification and pacer placement, and continuation of po Amiodarone.
   - Continue Amiodarone gtt as per EP
   - consider repeat cardioversion if remains in atrial fibrillation with
   24-48 hours of amiodarone / once amiodarone load felt to be adequate
   - Continue Vasopressin
   - Digoxin once weekly, 25% of original dose, per EP
   - off heparin [**2-19**] concern for intracranial bleed
   - IV Metoprolol as needed for rate control
   .
   # Cardiomyopathy: Newly-found EF of 20% with globally dilated RV.  Most
   likely tachycardia induced.  Was diuresed on Lasix drip initially, now
   monitoring central pressures with swan, currently volume overloaded but
   CVP WNL.
   - monitor I
s & O
s and cardiac index, titrate diuresis to CVP
   - ACE/BB once BP stabilizes and ARF improves
   -Lasix drip with metolazone for goal -1L today; will f/u I/O later
   -continue statin
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock:  Likely [**2-19**] Afib with RVR and/or infection/sepsis,
   briefly on 2 pressors, Levophed and Norsynephrine, currently only on
   Norepinephrine.  Cardiac index WNL and improved with titration of
   pressors. SVR still low at 400.
   - Continue to monitor cardiac index serially (once swan is replaced)
   - Goal negative 1L
 continue Lasix drip if necessary
   - Continue Amiodarone gtt
   .
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated on [**11-4**]/9 for increased work of
   breathing. Required increase in ventilatory support o/n, but CXR this
   AM improved.
   - titrate vent settings to ABGs, wean to PSV as tolerated
   - continue abx for now
   - CXR from [**2148-11-10**] showing ?consolidation at bases; previously with
   white out of left lung, ?mucus plug, now improved.
   - if febrile, consider broadening Abx coverage again
   .
   # Fevers: likely from positive influenza screen vs malignancy. ENT
   consulted, reports sinus opacity on head CT bleed rather than
   infection. Switched famotidine to PPI out of concern for drug fever.
   -Continue Oseltamivir (d4-5), Ramantadine for influenza A
   - f/u blood and urine cultures as well as influenza H1N1 send out
   - Continue Vancomycin, Ciprofloxacin, Ceftazidime
   - CXR from [**2148-11-10**] showing ?consolidation at bases; previously with
   white out of left lung, ?mucus plug, now improved
   .
   # [**Location (un) 10939**] Cell Carcinoma: Elevated LDH and finding of R axillary
   lymphadenopathy, CT torso showed c/w malignancy, biopsy consistent with
   Merckel Cell Carcinoma.  Poor prognosis at this time.
   - f/u Onc recs
   - f/u Derm recs, as there is an attending familiar with Merckel Cell
   Carcinoma.
   - f/u MRI results for
   - re-address code status
   .
   # Anemia/Thrombocytopenia: Crit stable, s/p transfusion.  Labs not
   concerning for DIC at this time.
   - Daily crit, transfuse for <25.
   - f/u HIT antibodies, still pending
   - guiac stools
   .
   # Acute renal failure: Cr trending down from peak 2.8, 1.8 today,
   baseline 1.1.  Likely [**2-19**] hypoperfusion given hypotension.  UOP
   adequate.  No indications for dialysis at this time.
   - Monitor [**Hospital1 **] electrolytes
   - follow UOP
   - Lasix drip if needed for goal -1L as above
   .
   # DMII: Last A1c in [**2-26**] was 7.4%. Will hold outpatient medications
   during this admission.   Sugars poorly controlled while in
patient,
   insulin drip intiated [**11-6**].
   - Continue Insulin drip
   .
   # Neurologic changes:  Concern for metastasis of malignancy affecting
   CNS vs. thormboembolic event given a fib, particularly given recent
   L-sided extremity weakness and confusion.   CT head negative for acute
   event, but significant for mass suggestive of metastatic malignancy.
   Mental status not improved today.  Unclear prognosis at this time given
   sedation requirements.
   .
   # Asymmetric LE edema: now appears more symmetric.  Likely secondary to
   HF.
   .
   # Hyperlipidemia: Cholesterol not well controlled according to last
   lipid panel measured in [**11-24**]. Chol: 295, LDL: 192, HDL: 79, TG: 120.
   Changed simvastatin 80mg PO daily to atorvastatin 40mg daily due to
   amiodarone presence and its potentiation of hepatotoxicity.
   - Follow LFT
   .
   # Arthritis: Stable.
   .
   # Gout: Stable.
   - Continue allopurinol 600mg PO daily; monitor renal function.
   .
   # Family Meeting:  Family updated daily.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. He presents with symptoms of malaise, dry cough, increasing dyspnea, and was found to have atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) and markedly decreased ejection fraction (EF) with dilated left ventricle. He underwent cardioversion multiple times but remains in and out of atrial fibrillation despite medication.

The patient is currently in the ICU due to respiratory failure and requires mechanical ventilation. He has a history of [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma and has been diagnosed with Merkel cell carcinoma. He also has anemia and thrombocytopenia, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus type II, neurologic changes, asymmetric lower extremity edema, hyperlipidemia, arthritis, and gout.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 104.5°F, blood pressure ranging from 125/57 mmHg to 149/65 mmHg, heart rate ranging from 67 to 158 bpm, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient is on multiple medications including amiodarone, vasopressin, norepinephrine, furosemide, metoprolol, and insulin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Atrial fibrillation with RVR:

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. He presents with symptoms of malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea. He was found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and markedly decreased ejection fraction with dilated left ventricle. He underwent cardioversion multiple times but remains in and out of atrial fibrillation. The patient also has a recent diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has acute renal failure, anemia, thrombocytopenia, and is suspected to have sepsis or infection. He requires vasopressors for hemodynamic instability. The patient's condition is complicated by multiple medical complications including cardiomyopathy, respiratory failure, hypotension, fever, and possible malignancy with metastasis.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's decreased ejection fraction and dilated left ventricle suggest a cardiomyopathy, which may be related to his recent diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient is intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. There is a concern for pneumonia or consolidation in the lungs.
3. Hypotension: The patient requires vasopressors to maintain blood pressure, indicating hypotension. This could be due to sepsis, cardiogenic shock

Summary:
Based on the provided information, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Intracranial bleeds: The patient has multiple enhancing lesions on MRI, which are consistent with extracerebral metastases. Additionally, there are new hyperdense foci in the right frontal area and right cerebellar area, which could represent intraparenchymal hemorrhage or metastasis. The attending physician's note mentions evolving hemorrhage and blood/fluid level layering within an extra-axial collection.

2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient has a significantly decreased ejection fraction (EF) of 20% with global dilation of the right ventricle. This may be due to tachycardia-induced cardiomyopathy. The patient is also experiencing diuretic resistance and hypotension, which may indicate cardiogenic shock.

3. Respiratory failure: The patient was intubated due to increased work of breathing and has been on ventilatory support. There is a concern for weaning off the ventilator and transitioning to pressure support ventilation (PSV).

4. Fevers: The patient has had a high fever of 104.5, likely due to influenza or Merkel cell carcinoma. Cultures have been sent, and there is a plan to repeat them if the patient continues to have fevers.

5. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating acute kidney injury. This could be secondary to hypoperfusion

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. He presents with symptoms of malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea. He has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and markedly decreased ejection fraction. He underwent cardioversion multiple times but remains in atrial fibrillation. The patient also has a new diagnosis of Merkel cell carcinoma, with evidence of metastasis to the brain and lymph nodes. He is experiencing hypotension, respiratory failure, fevers, acute renal failure, and anemia/thrombocytopenia. His condition is deteriorating, and he is not responding well to treatment.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Cardiogenic shock due to severe left ventricular dysfunction and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
2. Infection/sepsis leading to hypotension and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome.
3. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to severe lung infiltrates and respiratory failure.
4. Hepatic dysfunction due to amiodarone toxicity and potential metastasis of malignancy.
5. Renal failure secondary to hypoperfusion and use of diuretics.
6. Thromboembolic events such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE), especially with immobilization and atrial fibrillation.
7. Metastatic spread of Merkel cell carcinoma to other organs, including

   who presents with approximately 1 week of malaise, dry cough,
   increasing dyspnea and found to be in new-onset A.fib with RVR and
   markedly decreased EF with dilated LV, now s/p cardioversion x8, now
   with new [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma diagnosis and Influenza A.
   .
   # Hypotension/Shock:  Mixed cardiogenic and distributive picture.
   Likely [**2-19**] Afib with RVR, cardiomyopathy, metastatic carcinoma and/or
   infection/sepsis from influenza A, currently only on norepinephrine and
   dopamine, did not tolerate vasopressin.  Swan has been removed.
   - Continue pressor support
   - Continue Amiodarone gtt and digoxin
   - continue to treat infectious process with antibiotics as below
   .
   # Atrial fibrillation with RVR:  Unresponsive to multiple attempts at
   cardioversion, likely secondary to increased sympathetic tone from both
   [**Location (un) 10939**] cell carcinoma and influenza A.  The patient likely has a
   dilated cardiomyopathy that is either secondary to or worsened by the
   tachycardia.  The patient is intermittently in sinus rhythm continued
   on amiodarone gtt @1mg/min following large IV load.  The patient is s/p
   AVJ modification with some improvement in amount of time in sinus.
   - continue amiodoarone and digoxin once weekly, 25% of original dose,
   per EP
   - heparin gtt stopped [**2-19**] CT head findings (CHADS score 2; hypertension
   and DM)
   - IV Metoprolol as needed to rate control in 120
   .
   # Intracranial bleeds/Neurologic status
 CT head c contrast [**11-12**]
   showed no lesion worrisome for mass effect, but two new lesions (R
   frontal, R cerebellar) were noted worrisome for metastasis vs.
   intraparenchymal hemorrhage in comparison to prior CT head one week
   ago.  NSGY was consulted and agreed with plan to d/c heparin gtt.
   (attending addendum to CT read) There is now a definite blood/fluid
   level, layering within a 14mm (AP) likely extra-axial collection, in
   the region of the right frontal operculum (2:18), suggesting evolving
   hemorrhage. Its relation to the more anteriorly-located well-defined
   hyperdense focus is unclear. The additional focus, along the right
   lateral aspect of the tentorium cerebelli, level of the ambient
   cistern, was not clearly present and also may represent evolving
   hemorrhage.
   -          heparin gtt d/ced
   -          MRI head c/w single punctuate hemorrhage, unclear as to
   relationship to mets which are not intraparenchymal
   -          Consider repeat CT scan in several days to reassess
   bleeding, or earlier if clinical situation warrants.
   .

   likely tachycardia induced.  Was diuresed on Lasix drip initially, now
   monitoring central pressures with swan, currently volume overloaded but

   - monitor I
s & O
s, titrate diuresis to CVP

   - replace swan today pending family discussion of CMO

 vanc + CTZ + ciprofloxacin
   empirically for now.

 likely no chemotherapy

The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes. He presents with symptoms including malaise, dry cough, increasing dyspnea, new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, markedly decreased ejection fraction with dilated left ventricle, and a recent diagnosis of cutaneous neuroendocrine tumor with multiple metastases.

The patient has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on multiple life-support measures. His vital signs include a temperature of 104.7°F, heart rate in the 160s, blood pressure in the 40s, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 99%. He is intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

Imaging studies reveal multiple dural and subgaleal metastases, a mass encasing the right internal carotid, and possible cavernous sinus metastasis. The patient's condition is deteriorating rapidly, with worsening hypoxia and respiratory status.

1. Hypotension/Shock: The patient is experiencing hypotension despite being on multiple vasopressors. This may indicate cardiogenic shock due to dilated cardiomyopathy secondary to tachycardia or septic shock due to an infectious process.

Summary:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes who presented with malaise, dry cough, and increasing dyspnea. He was found to have new-onset atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and markedly decreased ejection fraction with dilated left ventricle. The patient underwent cardioversion eight times but remained unresponsive. He was diagnosed with Merkel cell carcinoma and influenza A.

The patient's current condition is critical, and he is intubated due to respiratory failure. He has been on mechanical ventilation, and his ventilatory support settings have been stable for days, but he is becoming more hypoxic. His lungs show worsened right-sided infiltrates and improved left-sided aeration on chest X-ray. He is febrile with a temperature of 104.5 degrees Fahrenheit overnight, likely from influenza or related to suprainfection of pneumonia.

The patient has hypotension and shock, likely secondary to cardiogenic and distributive causes such as atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, cardiomyopathy, metastatic carcinoma, and/or infection/sepsis from influenza A. He is on norepinephrine and dopamine but did not tolerate vasopressin. The patient also has anemia and thrombocytopenia, which are being managed with transfusions.

His renal function is impaired, with a creatinine level trending down from a peak of 2.8 to 2.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and lung cancer. He was admitted with new-onset rapid atrial fibrillation and severe cardiomyopathy, confirmed by an ejection fraction of 20%. The patient has been treated for influenza A and diagnosed with Merkel cell carcinoma. 

The patient's current condition is critical, with multiple organ dysfunctions. He is experiencing hypotension and shock, likely due to cardiogenic and distributive causes. He is unresponsive to multiple cardioversions, likely secondary to increased sympathetic tone from the underlying conditions. The patient has a dilated cardiomyopathy that may be secondary to or worsened by the tachycardia. He is currently on amiodarone and digoxin.

The patient also has respiratory failure, intubated on [date] for increased work of breathing. His ventilatory support settings are stable, but he appears to be becoming more hypoxic, unclear reason. There is suspicion of volume overload, pneumonia, and ARDS. 

The patient has fevers, likely from influenza or related to suprainfection of pneumonia with gram-negative rods. He is being treated with oseltamivir, ramantadine for influenza A, and antibiotics for suspected hospital-acquired pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia.

The patient has anemia and thrombocytopenia, which have been addressed with transfusion. There are concerns about acute renal failure, likely secondary to poor forward flow from hypotension/shock. 

The patient has diabetes mellitus type II, poorly controlled during this admission. 

Other conditions include asymmetric left lower extremity edema, likely secondary to volume overload, hyperlipidemia, gout, and arthritis.

A family meeting has been held, and the patient's code status is full code.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 65-year-old male with multiple medical conditions including hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, atrial fibrillation, and Merkel cell carcinoma. He was admitted for new onset rapid atrial fibrillation and severe cardiomyopathy.

The patient's current condition is critical, with several potential medical complications. These include:

1. Hypotension/Shock: The patient has a mixed cardiogenic and distributive picture of shock. This could be due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, cardiomyopathy, metastatic carcinoma, and/or infection/sepsis from influenza A. The patient is currently only on norepinephrine and dopamine, and did not tolerate vasopressin. Pressor support should be continued.

2. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response: The patient is unresponsive to multiple attempts at cardioversion, likely secondary to increased sympathetic tone from both Merkel cell carcinoma and influenza A. The patient likely has a dilated cardiomyopathy that is either secondary to or worsened by the tachycardia. Amiodarone and digoxin will be continued, and the patient should be monitored for rate control.

3. Intracranial bleeds/Neurologic status: The patient's CT head c/contrast showed two new lesions (R frontal, R cerebellar) that were noted worrisome for metastasis vs. intraparenchymal
